pros: Work life balance, vacation time, telework the opportunity to create, had a great team
cons: The e-team is very insecure which becomes very difficult to work with when tryimg to implement change. Managers could not handle critical feedback and often blamed others for issues without any self reflection. Managers are passive aggressive which leads to bad cross-departmental communication. Now being in a healthy work environment it is even more apparent how bad it was. Providing new ideas or trying to engage in brainstorms was not encouraged. Asking questions is not encouraged. The idea of the whole office being one big team working towards a common goal does not exisit which led to people becoming very defensive and not cooperative. Everyone always had a second agenda. Upper management was not genuine and very hard to work with especially because they have limited business acumen. Most of the managers like that had very little work experience outside ISEP so this culture is all they know. It is like being in high school in all the worst ways. They promote people not on their hard work but on cronisim. Mansplaining was a regular occurance and the culture is not positive for women. The e-team knows about the sexism and sexual harassment but if you try to report it you will be told, "oh but he didn't mean it," and nothing will happen.

pros:
-I've never worked anywhere with a better work/life balance. 
-You have the power and authority to present and pursue your ideas--if you are an early or mid-career professional, this is a great place to develop a lot of the skills that will get you to the next level (in other local organizations)
-Leadership is willing to takes risks and welcomes changes that can enhance operational effectiveness. 
-ISEP is a great place to work for young professionals that are new to DC, as there is a strong sense of community among staff
cons:
ISEP is a great place to work, but not forever. The organization does promote staff internally when a skilled candidate is available, and that person often becomes the highest performer at the next level. That said, the internal promotion is undervalued when it comes to salary, and it is rare that it gets evened out over time. There are very few opportunities for advancement within the organization.

Salary ranges are a mystery. The haziness around salary levels seems overly intentional, even when it is within your own team. While salaries have historically been lower than at competing DC non-profits, ISEP has taken positive steps to close that gap over that last year or so.

pros:
- ISEP is the friendliest, warmest place I've worked. The majority of people genuinely enjoy each other, which makes for good trust and collaboration between teams.
- The work-life balance is good, and there's flexibility when it comes to working remotely.
- Senior leadership seems keen to adjust and make changes to suit the needs of member institutions (which can be both a pro and a con), giving the organization a feeling of being nimble.
- In my experience, managers take feedback well and strive to allow professional development wherever possible on their teams. Managers are supportive of employees' ideas for additional projects.
- There's good trust and respect for the President of the organization
- Good benefits, including the holiday time between Christmas and New Year's.
cons:
- As a small organization, there aren't always opportunities for growth when you're ready to move into another position.
- The somewhat frequent reorganization of roles (see above, as this is also a pro) can give a sense of instability at times.
- Vacation and sick time are combined into PTO, which encourages people to work when they're sick, rather than reduce vacation time, which is not a healthy perspective.

review_title: Loved working here until big changes were made
pros: Great people who love what they do and are passionate about international education.  Good atmosphere (most of the time) and decent benefits (when I was there, there was a 10% 403b match but I hear that's been decreased.  Annual staff party, christmas party and staff usually young and hangs out with each other.  I absolutely loved working here for the first year and a half of my tenure, but then the management made some decisions that set the company in a direction that led many employees to quit.  Turnover is high.
cons: Management from the top down.  Not a lot of room for growth and somewhat cliquey.

pros: Great group of people to work with ad flexible work schedule
cons: Because salaries are so below the average in the industry, there is a lot of staff turnover. It is impossible for one to sustain a living in the DMV area with the current salaries.
